plist.p: Good morning, everyone. I'd like to welcome you to Telstra's Results for the Full Year 2011.

My name is Ben Spincer, Director of Investor Relations at Telstra. In a moment, I will hand over to David and John to run you through the results. After David and John have said some words to you, we will obviously take some questions both from my phone here in Melbourne and also from the phone lines.
I'll hand over to Telstra's CEO, David Thodey. Thank you.
Thanks, Ben, and let me add my welcome to the full year results. It's great to have you here.

I should quickly welcome a number of other people that are on webcast because we now are a multimedia company. Those watching T-Box Channel 409 and, of course, on BigPond News, which welcomes you as well. And I should quickly say this is an auspicious day for two reasons. Firstly, it is John's final results presentation, and John, I was just sort of saying before I think this is your 28th results briefing, 43 years in the company. So be kind to him when he gets up there. It's – the second thing, it's an auspicious day too, because on Tuesday it was the 30th anniversary of when we introduced mobiles into Australia and we did it with a press release. But what an incredible story that's been, and we'll talk a little bit about that this morning. And of course, John was there when mobiles were introduced into Australia, so it's great.

Okay. So we're going to follow pretty much the same format we normally do. I'm going to give you sort of the highlights of the business and then, really focusing on looking at how strategy is starting to deliver results, because at the end of the day strategy without results doesn't mean a whole lot. Then John is going to come up and take you through all the financial details, which are really important. There is a quite bit in them for this result. And then I'd like to come back at the end and try and give you a bit of sense of where we are at with NBN. I'm hoping that next year I don't have to talk about NBN, but, at least this year, I still do.

So, let's get on to the results. Look, I do need to say from the very beginning. Look we're very pleased with the results, especially the second half. The momentum in the business was strong. Revenue grew 0.7% for the full year, which is good, but in the second half we grew 1.8%, and that's just been very gratifying for the whole company.

While we still – as we forecast, the EBITDA declined 6.4% for the full year, however second half, up 0.7%. So, what we're seeing as the revenue flows through as we're managing our costs, a strong second half performance. And, of course, we've generated $5.5 billion of free cash. So, we'll take you through the detail of that. That's ahead of guidance and, in fact, we are ahead of guidance on all those metrics. So, really a set of solid results and I do just want to pause for a moment. It's not normal in results, but I want to thank all the Telstra staff, the senior team . Look, as you know, we've had a lot of work to do and we've still got lot of work ahead of us, but it's starting to pay results and we are really pleased with that. So, my colleagues and to all Telstra staff, thank you.

So as I said, John's going to take you through the results in more detail because always there's a lot of detail around what's really going underneath the business. But let me now turn to just some of the highlights from the business. It was a year ago when we came here and we said we're going to invest a significant amount of money to get momentum back in the business, to grow our customer base, increase market share, and very importantly, to simplify the business, and that was a big call.

And the second thing we said was we're really going to try to focus on our customers. Again, it's the beginning of the journey, but we think that we have really made some progress on it. So look, the key highlights as I sit back from the business that I'm very pleased about. Firstly our price points are simpler. I think we are becoming easier to do business with. I didn't say easy, but easier to do business with, and that's very important in dealing with our customers. And I think the way we're constructing our offers, there's good value for our customers while we still manage the core financials.

We're seeing very strong customer growth. In fact, in the end, it exceeded our own expectations. I'll come on to that in a moment, but 2 million mobile subscribers across our domestic and our Hong Kong business is a truly outstanding result. So, we're very pleased with that.

Also, in terms of the productivity, we've realized $622 million of productivity improvement from all the work that Robert Nason and the team and, in fact, the whole of the company has done in terms of the first year of the simplification process. And, of course, what we've seen is some of those benefits have flown through into the second half results.

So, customer service, fourth one. I'd say that some – more of our customers are starting to see the results. We want more of them to see a real difference, but we're starting – our customers are starting to say, hey, things are improving. I'll take you through some of that in a moment. And then, of course, we did finalize the NBN Definitive Agreements and we're now really looking forward to getting that to shareholders to give them the opportunity to vote on that in October, and more about that later on.

So, I think you can see from the top line results that the strategy is starting to take traction. It's starting to deliver results. So, our focus on customer satisfaction, customers in our 1, 2 and 3; always critically important. Secondly, about growing our customer base, really important; simplifying the business so we can do things better, faster in a more responsive way for our customers, and then also looking where we can find new areas of growth. So, what I'm going to do now is I'm just going to give you a quick update on each of those areas so you get a sense, at least from my perspective, about what we're seeing in the business.

So, let's talk about customer satisfaction. Now, two years we've started on this journey to really change Telstra, and that's both culturally, it's about process redesign, it's about our focus, and you've got to do them all together. And, it's about making this company faster and simpler to do business with. And as I said, well, I think we are seeing some early signs that these changes are starting to work. Obviously, you look at that and you say, well, one thing is how your customers feel about you but what are the actual results. The deactivation rates are a tremendous result. We have seen some of the lowest deactivation rates that I can remember in the business since I've been here. And when we survey our customers, and we do survey over 2,500 every month, they are saying things are improving, and that's really gratifying, in every segment of the market.

And we made a number of, what I would call, significant customer-focused changes in the organization last year. We set up the new Telstra Digital division, which is really very important, because this is all about interacting with our customers differently.

A very interesting statistic that even though we have grown our customer base significantly this year, interesting – the number of calls into our call centers has actually gone down. That means our customers are interacting differently, and they're still coming – ringing for sales. That's – so, we're reducing the number of service calls per customer and that's very, very important. And we think more of them are going online.

We launched these Freedom Connect mobile plans. Now, we launched many plans during the year, but these were a great testament of a simpler (8:00) model business plan, and also it had paperless bill and direct debit. Really important changes. And we've sold 320,000 of those new plans. That means the market is really picking those up.

Also, as you would have seen, we announced during the year that the LTE mobile network, we would roll it out this year. On Monday, we put out 2,000 of the dongles to business customers and will have a commercial launch later this month. So that's been really gratifying. The engineering guys are working hard to make that network really one of the world's best.

Also, as you know, we have changed the way we are serving our customers with 24/7 call centers. We've done that. We are doing field calls in the weekend with nets growing and customers saying hey, come to see us in the weekend. And very interesting, we've gone to 24 hour support on social networking sites. We're seeing a lot of customers going to social networking sites, and now we got people 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, just monitoring those sites, so we can respond to customers.

These are real changes in how the whole business is operating. So we're very committed to improving customer satisfaction. And while we're very pleased with the progress we're making, we do know, and I want to stress, there's still a lot of opportunities to do even better as we go forward.

As I said, customer growth is critically important to us, and I show this chart every quarter. And the real message here is that the fourth quarter growth continued. And that was very important as we came through the year that we didn't see the fourth quarter drop off.

As you see there, 378,000 new mobile customers in the fourth quarter, which brought us to just on 1.7 million for the year domestically. 92,000 new bundles were sold in the fourth quarter. That's over 650,000 for the full year, and remember, bundles are really important because customers sign up for two-year contract. And then 203,000 new mobile broadband customers in the quarter and 914,000 for the full year.
They are really impressive numbers. But also, you're starting to see a change in the way people are using broadband services and this is -we see great future for this business.

But, net growth has got to translate into revenue and profit growth because it's not sustainable to keep just growing your customer base. You got to get real results coming out. So, as you would have seen, mobiles growth, 10.7%, and fixed broadband at 1.4%. You've got to compare that to last year, where it was far less. So really encouraging, good customer growth and also now starting to see in the second half flowing through into good top line growth. And John will take you through the margins as well, which are really important.

Okay, our simplification efforts, really important, because this is where we're really trying to drive out a different way of running the business. And this is all about driving out real, sustainable net reductions in terms of our operating costs over time. We are redesigning over 300 processes at 27 projects and, as you can imagine, that takes a lot of effort to get going.

Importantly, simplifying the business has resulted in a very important decline. When we look at labor and productivity, we look at labor and labor substitution because, remember, we do outsourcing. So when you look at the results of the full year, and you'll see that labor has gone up, but if you look at it by quarter, you have seen this progressive decline as we have moved through the year as we try to simplify the processes, and we are able to get real productivity improvements.

So what we're doing with those improvements, some of it's going to the bottom line, some of it we are reinvesting in new parts of the business. As you know, we're reinvesting in the Network Applications and Services business, which is a very people-intensive business. So we've been able to invest there. We have also been able to support the Sensis digital strategy which is very important, this three-year transformation. And then we've setup Telstra Digital and now we've got the new Telstra Applications and Ventures Group, which we're setting up, which is a whole new way that we are going to be competing in the NBN world.

So the program we work is very simple. It's simplified process that allows us to take costs out of the business to serve our customers better. We've got to do all three. And we have got to continue with this focus. I think it's every day, every week, every year for the future because it's just the way we want to do our business. So great progress in that area but still a lot more to be done. We all see great opportunity to do even more as we move forward.

In terms of the growth businesses, let me now turn to those. Remember, there's three of them; Network Application and Services, Media, and International. I just want to briefly touch on how each one of these are going.

Now, Network Applications and Services, just, I want to restate. What is it? Well, it is about outsourcing of networks from large customers where we take over the whole of the operation. It's about cloud computing, so when we take over the computing capability in the business and we put it on a shared infrastructure.

It's about things like systems integration, when you rollout unified communications or you're putting in a video conferencing solution, you need someone to come and wrap everything together and integrate it to a solution. That's a very different business to just selling carriage, but it's very related.

So that's what Network Applications is. It's quite simple but a very different business model because you need methodology, you need very experienced people, and you need to manage every project for profitability, as well.

We're seeing great progress there. It's now a billion dollar business and it grew revenue at 10.7% and the profitability improved. The net sales pipeline is very strong as we come into the year and that sets us up well because many of these big contracts are very large and they're 10 year contracts, eight year contracts and if you get those then you get good sustainable revenues moving forward.

And we also made a number of significant announcements during the year. Remember, we said, $800 million into cloud computing. That's a significant investment and that's over a five year period, but we're already well on the way and I think we're being recognized as well as one of the best cloud computing suppliers in Australia, and even throughout Asia.

We launched a very important product in the small and medium business, which is called Digital business. Now, it hasn't got a lot of headlines, but it's very, very different, because it works off the IP network and it gives an integrated voice and broadband integrated solution for the small and medium business that is easy to use, easy to implement and we support it and it's a different pricing model. This is all about being ready for an NBN world. We can offer the product now and its NBN ready as soon as you put it in. Very important. So, we're already on the way to being ready to compete in the NBN world.

And then, late in the year, we did the acquisition of iVision which is a video conferencing business. It was pretty small, because we're really buying capability that will allow us to integrate high definition video conferencing both in business, but that will very quickly move into the consumer home market. So, and then you're going to get the integration between business and the home in terms of how education and health services are delivered. So, this was a very strategic capability acquisition. So, all that and now we are looking at the Application & Ventures Group that Dean is going to lead which is going to look at investing in new applications that will enable us to really compete in this NBN world with a differentiated cloud offering across industry verticals and horizontals. So, some really good progress there.

Now, in terms of International, I've been very – well, tried be very clear on this. We want to drive value from Asia. We have got presence across Europe and in the United States but it's really in Asia where we really believe our strength is and, as I keep saying, we've been in Asia for 65 years. It's not like this is new. We do about $1.5 billion in international. It's not like this is just a new add on to the business. But I'm very pleased with the progress we have had. We brought the Reach asset, remember that was the old OTC, back into Telstra and it was a good, good way of bringing it back in and now gives us great access into Malaysia, Indonesia, Korea, the Philippines and that's where we need to go, where there is real growth economies and population growth is going well. So that's very important for us as we go forward. But remember it's not just about cable networks, it's about adding value around those communication networks.

Also, CSL, I'm delighted to say, returned to a very strong growth profile. They had, in local currency, 19% growth, which is tremendous. Their services growth is running at 7% so I'm very pleased about the CSL results and that's been a business that we've had to really work hard at over the last few years.

Now, in terms of the China digital media assets, as you know we did the SouFun sale earlier in the year. I do want to just say that we are – we are reviewing all these assets. I want to make sure that they're going to really deliver value. So, we have that portfolio under review at the moment. Okay, so last area is the media portfolio. Remember, in media portfolio we put there Sensis, BigPond, FOXTEL and of course the T-Box IP TV. So, let me just give you a quick update on how we're traveling there.

So first the IPTV. We've been pleasantly surprised about the response to IPTV and T-Box. 190,000 units were sold during the year. It's been very interesting looking at the video-on-demand or download of those movies. We've now got a library around about 2,400 to 2,500 but there's been 1.8 million, 1.8 million movies downloaded since we had the product. It's a very interesting change in the way people are watching movies and we think, like Netflix in the U.S., we have a good market opportunity as we go forward.

Also, we've entered into strategic partnerships with all the major movie studios and so we think we're well positioned there. We also announced FOXTEL Services on the T-Box so we've got 30 FOXTEL channels and within just the first few weeks we had a thousand people sign up on FOXTEL Channels on the T-Box, so that's been great. And of course, FOXTEL has also had a strong year. They continue to do very well. Revenue growth of 6%. EBITDA is up 15%.

Now, I should quickly mention Austar. As you know, we're going through the process with ACCC and we're working closely with FOXTEL. We do really want to exercise this to its final conclusion and we really support FOXTEL in this acquisition.

In terms of BigPond, we've had a strong year in BigPond. The number of actual visitors to the BigPond online and mobile sites has gone up and it's all about getting eyeballs to those sites. And our content deal with AFL will also allow us to provide AFL matches live on mobiles and tablets connected to the Next G network and also on FOXTEL via T-Box. So you can see getting content we have to put through multiple channels is very important in terms of our ongoing strategy. Then lastly, let me talk about Sensis, which is really important and I know that at the half and then we announced just a change in that business and then Bruce did a very fulsome explanation of our strategy.

As you know, we are transitioning this business to digital media, sort of a local digital media company and we are on the way. For the full year, as we did guide to you, revenue decline was 6.4% and EBITDA was 9.4% and this is really the shift from print to online. However, it is a three-year transformation and we've tried to lay out to you how we think that's going to go and we are really only a few months into the sales cycle. Remember, we run the sales cycle (20:46). We get out there but we are seeing some very positive indicators as we are seeing the market reaction to the product. Firstly, the new packages have been really received well.

The small and medium business, they wanted to be educated and they want to know someone who can them move into an online world. So we've been very strong there. The sign up rate, interestingly, and revenue per customer on what we call the value packages, which is a mixture of print and digital, have been very well received and the revenue per customer has been higher than we had anticipated. Because that's offsetted by the print decline, so we just got to work that different business model as it goes forward. In the second half of fiscal 2011, digital revenues grew by 12.8%. So you can see – remember it was only 0.2% in the first half, really strong result in the second half. So, it still early days, a lot of work to be done and I think if Bruce were up here he'd say, look, some early signs, I'm not declaring victory but we got some really positive indicators here as we move forward. And I'm really confident as the board and I went through and spent some time with the whole of the Sensis team in the last few days, we're seeing good strategy, the product offering is good and now it's about execution. And that's going to take time because it's a real different business model as we move forward. So, so far so good, but more work to be done.

I want to put this chart up just very briefly. This was a chart I showed you last year to try to give you some sense about what would be the lead indicators in terms of how our strategy is playing out. As you'll see up there on the chart, all of it going pretty well except for customer service. We've still got, in terms of our aspirations, while it's improving, we're not quite where we want to be. The number of complaints coming through is still a little bit higher than we wanted. We want to manage those. Not that – but I have a different view. Complaint's good because I see there is an opportunity, an opportunity to fix and to win the customer heart in some way.

However, we don't want the same level of complaints. Also, I think that there is more work we can do in terms of getting this net promoter score and net satisfaction index score really up where we need to get it. But all the other areas going well. As you can see, the revenue from business growth area is already at 19%. We may have to review that target. We may be able to push that harder.

Okay, let me finish up before I hand it over to John with the guidance for next year. So, for 2012 fiscal year, we see momentum continuing through. So, our forecast, despite the market uncertainties, is that we will have low single-digit growth to both revenue and EBITDA flowing through.

CapEx will continue to be around 14% of sales because we've still got some investments to do in terms of building out our capability, especially in – as we get ready for NBN. Cash, and John will take you through, still at 4.5% to 5% and John will just give you an explanation of that because even though we're just a little bit over 5%, there are just some puts and takes on that line. I will say again, as we've said before, we are committed to pay a dividend of $0.28 per share, fully franked, as we go into the year.

And in terms of capital management, I want to say again, the board is committed to reviewing our capital management strategy, but we said we have to get through NBN and then see how that plays out and then we'll come and talk to you about what we were doing.
But I do want to add just one more proviso. Obviously, it is subject to what the global financial conditions will be, as you'd expect, and they going through a bit of change a the moment.

A couple of last points. NBN is not expected to have a material impact on Telstra's financial results in fiscal year '12 but it will contribute to sustainable cash flow generation for Telstra in the medium term.
So with that, John, let me get you up for your last set of financial results.
Thanks, David, and good morning everyone. It's great to be here today to take you through a strong set of results and particularly because they're the – last one I'll be doing.

First, I'll take you through the K-reported numbers. You've seen I believe already from David, but on the top line, sales revenue grew 0.7% to $25 billion in fiscal year 2011, including 1.8% in the second half, as the strong growth in our customer base started to come through in the revenue line. Following the strategic OpEx initiatives this financial year, operating expenses did increase by 6.8% or $970 million to $15.2 billion. EBITDA was down 6.4%, or $696 million, to $10.15 billion with margins contracting by 3 percentage points to 40.6%. Importantly in the second half, EBITDA was positive growing 0.7% as we translated as our strategic initiatives into the bottom line benefits. EBIT fell 12.4% or $809 million to $5.7 billion, with the decline in the second half just 1.6%. And profit after tax and minorities fell 16.8%, or $652 million, to $3.2 billion. Free cash flow was $5.5 billion, and declined due to lower EBITDA following the strategic initiatives. And excluding the process from the sale of SouFun and other small assets, free cash flow was $5.2 billion.

And we have maintained our final fully franked ordinary dividend at $0.14 per share bringing the total for the fiscal year to $0.28. Our dividend continues, importantly, to be covered by free cash flow. On a guidance basis, so that's adjusting for some ACCC fixed line pricing changes and the impact of natural disasters, sales revenue actually grew by 1%, so real underlying performance there. Adjusting for the impairments of Octave and L Mobile and the cost of natural disasters and the impact of the Reg. change OpEx was up 6.4%, and so on a guidance basis, EBITDA declined 6%. We've not adjusted the results for FX impacts, but if we did, sales this year would increase by $161 million or another 0.6% on the revenue growth line.

So, let's just take a look at product revenues. In terms of the product revenues, this slide gives you an overview of the puts and takes that have occurred during the year. The growth in mobiles, as you can see from the slide more than offset the PSTN headwind, or decline. Mobile revenues increased by $783 million or 10.7% to nearly $8.1 billion, as our strategy of retaining and growing that customer base led to the addition, as you heard David say, of 1.66 million new customers in Australia this year.

The PSTN revenues, as you see can see from the slide, declined by 7.9%, or $462 million, as the usage levels continue to fall in line with global trends and the continuing trend to move to social networks and mobile, of course. The retail fixed broadband revenues increased 1.4%, though declines in wholesale broadband offset this. IP, access, and data revenues were flattish with a 16.2% increase, importantly in new technology, in the IP access. But it was offset by declines in the all legacy data products and Network Applications and Services, as David said, grew at 10.7%, or $111 million, while Sensis revenue did decline by $122 million, or 6.4%.

I'm delighted, actually, to be able to talk about how well the strategic initiatives have delivered on the financial outcomes. And this slide highlights some of those key outcomes. Firstly, solid sales revenue growth in each of our three retail business units, a 6 percentage point increase in mobile EBITDA margins from the first half to the second half. And I remember many of you remarking about the 29% that we had at the half. We know, we're now back up to the 35% EBITDA margins.

Continued growth in the Mobiles revenue with growth in the second half of the fiscal year at 11.4%. So that momentum, and the revenue coming from the higher customer base starting to flow through. Market share gains of 3 percentage points in Mobiles and 1 percentage point in Fixed Retail Broadband. So, all that performance in the areas that I've just discussed, really does bodes well for the future and the momentum into the fiscal year 2012.

I just want to visit the part (31:00), not all 44 years of my career but last year, we told you – or I told you that we intended to invest around $1 billion. That was a sort of approximation that we were talking about at this time last year to improve customer service and to grow and retain our customers and simplify our business and core processes and invest in new revenue streams. Fundamentally, that was the strategy and that's where we're investing money.

Let me just now close the loop on those investments. You can see during the financial year, our OpEx increased by $970 million, so close to the approximate $1 billion that I was talking about. And this included a $670 million increase in mobile directly variable costs and network payments and $159 million increase in the new products area, so investing in our new product growth. Goods and services totaled an increase of $823 million and I said that that will be around $650 million.

But as I told you in February, so as we move through the fiscal year '11, the DVCs came in a bit more above our initial expectations. However, the benefits, in terms of customer retention and growth, is clear. We did add 1.66 million domestic mobile customers, 365,000 T-Boxes and T-Hubs, and 659,000 bundled customers, much more than we expected. And as I said at the half year announcement, we kept the momentum going and we said we would absorb that within that around a $1 billion investment and we did, and remained within our guidance. So, I think that's very important. We said we – what we would do back at the half, and we did it.

Let me just move on to ARPU trends, because these are important, as well, to the top line. I want to just update you on those. And as I said, again in February at the results briefing, we have seen a modest decline in ARPUs across Mobile and Fixed Broadband, as the customers do move to our more competitively priced offerings. This is in line with our expectations and is more than offset by our customer growth.

In Mobile Handheld postpaid, the impact of growth in capped plans was partly offset by the growth in smartphone penetration. And there is also an impact from MRO plans on this ARPU but that's more obviously a non-cash accounting impact. In postpaid, ARPU declines have also been driven by the growth in prepaid capped plans. But while in mobile broadband, the ongoing trend of ARPU decline is driven by price competition but also the increase in prepaid penetration in mobile broadband with tablets, etcetera.

I want to again highlight that the mix in bundles, so the net mix in bundles, is revenue accretive. This is due to the new customers acquired and existing customers taking an additional product, and, of course, reduced churn as existing customers accept multi-product discounts. On churn, the activation rate for postpaid handheld mobiles, as you saw from David's slide, has fallen nearly – from 12.4% to 8.8%.

Now let me talk about some of the margins and I've already alluded to the Mobile margin but this, of course, is a critical measure for us to track our progress with our strategy. It's not just about revenue growth, it's also about EBITDA improvement. You see the Mobiles EBITDA margins declined in the first half because we invested quite heavily in the first half to retain and grow the customer base. However, that level of spending tailed off and so Mobile EBITDA margins returned in the second half to last year's levels of 35%. And you can see for the full year there, Mobile EBITDA margins were 32%, which is a solid result given the investment we made in the customer base. The Fixed Internet margins remains subdued due to the impact of some of the regulatory changes on pricing, but also the ARPU reduced because of our own competitive retail offerings in the market. As the cost base went up, as we had data allowances, it does introduce more cost into the company, of course.

The PSTN margins remained relatively stable with the decline in revenue and ARPU offset by continued tight cost control. And IP, Access, and Data margins were also stable as customers continue to migrate to IP access, products from the old data legacy networks. And Sensis margins bounced back in the second half, albeit on a reduced revenue base.

Let me just touch on the retail segments here because this is also important. All three retail segments had solid top line growth this financial year, and that's a great performance. Telstra Consumer and Country Wide sales revenue grew 3.6% as the strategic initiatives delivered strong growth in the customer base, including adding 0.5 million postpaid mobile customers and 160,000 fixed retail broadband customers. And in Consumer, total mobile revenue grew 12.9%, while prepaid mobile revenue share grew by several percentage points. From a profitability perspective, as I said last August, operating contribution margins bounced back in the second half to 56%, as the growth in the customer base in the first half translated into revenues in the second half.

Telstra business revenue increased by 1.8%, with a growth in mobile offsetting the headwinds from PSTN declines and during the year mobile ARPUs have held up well in spite of some price rebalancing that took place for business customers. Telstra Business' revenue from IP Access and Network Applications and Services reached $300 million this year. And in recent months, the Digital Business product suite was launched to give small to medium enterprises access to unified communications. In addition to being a great set of products, the Digital Business product suite makes us NBN-ready in the SME space.

Lastly, Telstra Enterprise and Government sales revenue also increased by 1.8% with mobile services revenue growth in that segment growing 11.8% and IP access growth of 14.8%. We've increased our focus in Enterprise and Government on network applications and service, and we announced we would invest more than $800 million in cloud computing over the next five years to support the growing demand for cloud services.

So let's get into OpEx and it's important to explain the 6.8% operational expense increase in the year, some of it I've already talked about in terms of DVCs, but the – it did increase $970 million to $15.2 billion. So in terms of the way we traditionally report expenses, labor, goods and services, I'll take you through those categories in a moment. But firstly, I want to explain the increase in the context of expenses incurred as a result of some of the one-off things that have happened in the year, the costs related to growth and – which have been offset by some productivity benefits. You'll recognize that $622 million that David spoke about there. I just want to say that doesn't include avoided costs by the way, those are net costs. So, we've also, in our productivity programs, we've avoided some costs that may otherwise have occurred as well. You'll recall I said that a productivity dividend would come in the second half of fiscal year '11 and then flow through into fiscal year '12. And you'll recall I said mostly the first half in the fiscal year just gone was about getting the initiatives in to place and then second half's been about implementation, with more implementation to go.

During the year, we generated productivity benefits of $622 million, as the simplification program delivered tangible results, and these benefits have been reinvested into the business to actually retain and grow our customer base and improve the things that we do to increase customer satisfaction. And this will invest in our long-term growth in the business. And as reported today, these investments are delivering.

So, let me get to the traditional view of expenses. Labor expenses increased by 5.9% or $270 million, to $3.9 billion. Among factors contributing to the increases were some one-offs including incremental staff incentive plans of $93 million, that's of the far left of the chart there, and which accrued after targets were hit. So, as you heard David said, we've had good performance in increasing customer satisfaction.

We had some additional Labor costs associated with the natural disasters, Queensland and in New Zealand as well. We've also incurred an increase in costs due to wage inflation and other price-related factors of $123 million. You can see on the slide but we have reduced our staff numbers.

And as you saw in David's slide pack regarding simplification, our domestic labor and labor substitution expenses fell through the year on a normalized basis. So at the start of the year we had to put some staff and to do some particularly things with relation to customer satisfaction, and as the productivity program and simplification cut in, that started to decline, and that's what reflected in David's slide on a quarter-by-quarter basis.

With respect to Goods and Services costs, they increased 15.4%, or $823 million, primarily due to our strategy to retain and grow the customer base, so mostly directly variable cost. Cost of goods sold increased $568 million to $2.6 billion, including $426 million of mobile cost of goods sold and $71 million in other cost of good sold such as T-Boxes and T-Hubs.

An increasing penetration of smartphones lifted the blended subscriber acquisition and rate (42:35) contracting costs by 34.7% to $212 from $157 and this investment in COGS generated more than 2 million new mobile customers in Australia and Hong Kong and the 365,000 T-Boxes and T-Hubs customers.

Part of the higher COGS cost was offset by an increase of more than $300 million in mobile hardware revenue. So obviously, as we sell the handsets, the revenue comes through. We also expect ongoing additional revenues from the larger mobile base in terms of service revenue as we go forward.

While talking about mobile variable costs, let me, perhaps, pre-empt a question that may come later. We did introduce zero MRO plans, so zero Mobile Repayment Options, planned in December and we have calculated that the EBITDA benefit in the half has been less than $100 million. And the zero MRO has improved mobile EBITDA margins in the second half by around 1%.

Network payments increased by $135 million, or 7.5% to $1.9 billion, as our larger mobile customer base incurred higher terminating volumes as traffic was terminated on other networks. Service fees increased by nearly $100 million, with the primary driver being the corresponding increase in Pay TV revenue growth and our FOXTEL in our bundles is an important offer and it is very much a churn mitigate.

So our other expense category, Service Contracts and Other Agreements sort of dominates this category. It did increase 3.7% due to the investments in some of the strategic initiatives early in the year, as I alluded to. For example, amongst the current initiatives to improve customer satisfaction were improvements to the Telstra Online portal and more after our service options for our customers with 24/7 service and weekend visits by technicians.

General & Administration costs fell by 3%, or $28 million, and the key driver was a $50 million reductions in IT costs due to renegotiated licenses and lower leasing arrangements. And bad and Doubtful Debts declined 7.9%, which is a great result. We invested heavily in credit management and implemented a series of initiatives to minimize bad debts, and these have included some early intervention of overdue accounts by proactively engaging with our customers and some more sophisticated credit assessments in our front of house.

So cash – cash and accrued CapEx. Free cash flow was $5.5 billion this year, which included $324 million cash proceeds from the sale of assets of which SouFun was the largest. And as I indicated to you at the half, the free cash flow was weighted towards the second half, as you can see by the coloring on the above in the slide, and the timing is because of the CapEx cycle, our incentive payments to staff, and some other cyclical factors.

Importantly for investors, free cash flow levels continue to comfortably cover the current dividend and interest commitments. In respect of CapEx, accrued operating CapEx was $3.4 billion, down $1.8 million -1.8% sorry, and $61 million. The biggest driver of the decline was 20%, or $146 million decline in what we call the business improvement CapEx driven by a lot of spend on IT projects as we still come down off of our transformation program.

Just the impact on NBN, just quickly. As we said the impact of NBN and our financials won't be significant in fiscal year '12. And I want to help you to start thinking about the impact of NBN on our financials in coming years. In addition to our usual reporting, we intend to provide extra information to help you model and track the progress of our agreements with NBN. So as NBN is rolled out, there will be additional reporting lines for physicals, revenues and expenses.

On our revenues side, we plan to report separately for key items including disconnections to NBN and infrastructure payments. And on the expense side, there will be NBN access costs and some additional remediation and ongoing maintenance costs that we will report. And we also plan to update you on key physicals such as the number of PSTN disconnected and the NBN access lines taken by Telstra customers. And of course, we will continue to report the legacy fiscal such as PSTN, and ULL lines, and LSS, and so on. In our results announcement next February, we hope to give you more detail on the additional reporting we plan to have going forward.

So, back to the guidance that David had up before and a bit of an explanation. Over the next fiscal year, we expect a positive momentum from the strategy we're on to continue. We expect both revenue growth and EBITDA growth to be in the low single-digits. CapEx to sales will continue to be around 14% of sales and the reason for that is that we do have to make some investments in being NBN-ready in terms of our interface with NBN but also taking some good product to market to encourage people to stay with us or come over to us in terms of our NBN offerings.

And free cash flow guidance is for between $4.5 billion and $5 billion. As always, and this is an important point, this free cash flow guidance does anticipate $500 million of investing capital spend. In fiscal year '11 we only spent $40 million, which clearly did contribute to our strong free cash flow result in fiscal year '11.

As announced last November, it is also the board's intention to maintain a $0.28 fully franked dividend for fiscal 2012, of course subject to the normal process of declaration and no unexpected material events. And the NBN, as I said, not expected to impact this guidance at all. But I do want you to note that we have moved to a total revenue guidance measure. It's previously been sales revenue. And there is nothing sinister in this, but given that, going forward, much of the income from NBN arrangements will be booked as Other Revenue and not Sales Revenue, so the decommissioning part of the revenue received, we have made the change, you see, so that in future years we can capture that in our guidance and you can understand what's going on.
So thank you for that, and I will just turn it back to David to wrap up.
Thanks, John. Great set of results, and thanks for your presentation. Okay.
What I'd like to do just at the end here is just to give you bit of a sense of where we are at with NBN and then we'll take your questions.

As you know, we have signed definitive agreements both with the government and NBN Co., and that was done in June. And we also submitted the structural separation undertaking with the ACCC, which was done a few weeks ago. I mean these have actually been really important milestones to get behind us and have taken a lot of work right across the company to get that done, and looking forward, we are now working on this expansion memorandum to get to our shareholders so you can understand the transaction and the basis for the board's recommendation to our shareholders.

It has really been a – I can't stress this enough – a critical few months for us. I mean it's a lot of work to get this thing done. And submitting the structural separation undertaking working with the ACCC in that process was really important. We did it very differently than the way we've done it before. So now we're currently focused on working with the ACCC to get the approval and get these EM's out so that we hopefully can get it to shareholders at the 18th of October, at the AGM.

What I'd like to do is just focus on what we think the three high level real benefits are to this transaction. And I'm not going (52:02) because as you would expect that will be in EM. So firstly, the agreement should provide a better financial outcome as compared to alternatives for the company and it will really contribute to sustainable free cash flow over that medium term and that is a very important consideration.

Secondly, getting to a more stable regulatory environment is very important. If we can get to a more stable regulatory environment it allows us to get on and focus on the business and our customers. And that is a very important thing to Telstra. And then looking at it from my perspective, having more strategic flexibility in what we do with cash and where we go to, is a real positive for us and it allows us as I've said before, to focus on growth opportunities and how we simplify the business, I do want to also to stress that we have to be conscious about what protections we've got in the future. I've mentioned these before and it's important just to mention them again.

Remember, we get this long-term contractual commitment from NBN Co. for structure; and remember, at any point should there be any changes, we have protection for that going forward. That's the first one. We've talked about the rollout termination payment of up to $500 million, now that's in the event that NBN ceases its rollout – after it's got to 20% of the 93% of premises in Australia. So that only kicks at that 20% level.

And also, it was a very important right that John negotiated. Remember, that we can continue to operate the copper network, the fixed-line business, in areas where the NBN fiber access does not go to. So, we call this the natural hedge, because that's very important to us, and you've got to factor that into your consideration.

So, it's important to remember as you think about this transaction, that at the moment, this is legislated government policy. And NBN Co. is now an operating business. It's commenced it's rollout of NBN and it's already started to provide services in a small number of areas, trial areas.

We are obliged to assess our options against presumption of alternative policies. We have to look at what's in front of us today or we can't assume NBN is not going to be built as planned. We can only look at the alternatives in light of current legislation and provide maximum flexibility in light of any potential changes in the future, and that's the way we have looked at this transaction.
What I do also want to just touch on is we have already doing a lot of work about our preparedness in terms of each of – go-to-market segments.

But we'll be talking through more of this in Investor Day but let me just quickly touch on each of the four key areas and just give you some sense about what we think the implications will be. In Telstra Consumer and Country Wide, obviously NBN residences (55:22) will make a change in how we provide fixed services to our customers. But we also offer a lot more to our customer than just fixed broadband services, with our world leading mobile network but also NBN is going to provide us with the opportunity to further build product innovation into our offering go-to-market and that's what we expect we're going to work on at the moment and of course the bundling services will be very important around content and things like that.

In Telstra Business, we've already talked about the wonderful Digital Business product and we're going to start to build out that product now because that is the way of the world to move to IP networks and an integrated service, and that would have happened with NBN or without NBN. And you go quite across the world, it's just a matter of the timing of when it happens and how you get there financially.

In terms of Enterprise and Government, the truth is that many of our Enterprise and Government customers today already use fiber. So the impact on the Enterprise and Government sector is probably more upside than downside and we see great opportunities going forward.

Of course, Telstra Wholesale, it will have a significant impact on those revenues because we have provided wholesale services across the copper access network and of course they will be disconnected over time. However, all the infrastructure payments from NBN will also flow into Wholesale, so there is some balancing effect as we move forward.
So, that's just an important set of considerations, we'll take you through more at Investor Day, but I want you to know that we're already working diligently in each of those market segments.

So let's just briefly touch on the structural separation undertaking in the migration plan that we submitted to the ACCC. In our undertakings, we have really tried to make a genuine attempt to take notice of the concerns raised by the industry and ACCC. So this issue is really an attempt to address some of these concerns and the points raised in the ministerial instruments. This is a substandard proposal and we have really spent a lot of time trying to think through how we could put something that would be acceptable to the ACCC and the industry but also not drive a lot of change within the company except than how we are really more transparent and provide more equivalents. So a few points to note. This is a very important point. We have not been asked to functionally separate and we are – but we are committed to providing equivalents and transparency. They are very, very different things very, very different.

In terms of our interim equivalents and transparency there are seven key areas that we've – you see on the chart behind me that we think really do make a substantive difference and they're not window dressing. They are real, real offerings of change. So we're working closely with ACCC with a view of obtaining acceptance to the structural separation undertaking before the AGM. However, I've got to be clear, if the ACCC has not given approval for this issue, which as you know, is a condition precedent, we may still take the decision for this transaction to our shareholders at the AGM, but the commencement of the agreement will still be subject to gaining the necessary approvals from the ACCC. So we're trying to balance this as we go through because there is a still a lot of work to be done.

Okay, so let's try to wrap up now. So I want to leave you really what I think are the key messages from both John's and my presentation. It's great to have exceeded guidance. It's a really pleasing result for us. We have basically done what we said we're going to do.

The customer growth achieved in the year is now translating into financial benefits and we returned to EBITDA growth in the second half, which is great, and we see that momentum continuing through into next year.

Yeah, because it's still going to be the same asset base that – calculation, right? Good morning, guys. Congratulations on the results. Two questions from me. Firstly, in terms of guidance. Yeah, that's right.
I think that's the – so look we obviously want to do as well as we possibly can but we're not giving specific guidance.

Now, in terms of the key risks for next year, well look, as with all these things, we are concerned about the markets. Consumer confidence I think we've talked about. Ian asked a question earlier on, though we are not seeing any real pull through on that at the moment.
We are concerned about and thinking about competition and pricing. What's going to happen in pricing. But the early signs for the last three months has been pretty reasonable.

And I think that – I'm sure there will be some sharpening of pencils in certain areas, but remember, this is all about targeting the right segments you want to go after, and really being considerate about how you can differentiate their offerings. So I see that as a ongoing challenge.

I think for the industry, the bigger challenge here is the expectation of customers on unlimited data plans. It is not sustainable, and it is not good for the industry. And as voice calling goes to IP, how you manage that transition and move from access to usage.
Now the big challenges of the industry around the world is really focused on. You've seen the U.S. go to unlimited plans, but they're all coming back now to more, I think, sensible approach.

You saw in Holland, a disruptive play with – on SMS. Free SMS. But it was only for a year before you start to have to pay for it. And you've seen us respond with all included SMS to try to get ahead of some of these things. So we look at disruptive plays where someone can come into the market and just start to completely change the model.

Obviously, you've got Microsoft going with Skype. You got Vonage. So how's that's going to play out and what's the true impact. So we're already starting to look at different pricing models to cover that off now. That's why access pricing and all included usage is very important as we move forward. Wireless broadband ARPU has declined. Well, yes that has been the challenge in the industry. LTE was not just a price play it was a unit cost play, because LTE manages that data on the wireless network far more efficiently, and therefore it allows – gives us some options going forward.

I would like to see ARPUs start to stabilize in the wireless broadband market, but we need to remain to be competitive, and we are not going to just let that sort of get away on us. My question, David, is about the NBN. And I'd like to go to your remarks where you talked about legislative government policy. Of course, government policy typically goes some distance beyond the legislation, and in the case of the NBN, I think that's certainly the case.
